subject: Naming, children and siblings
instructions: Welcome to Emmet Practice, a playground where you practice emmet abbreviations to write super fast HTML code!
In the next few exercises you will learn the basic rules of emmet abbreviations.
Edit the text in the Emmet editor to match with the expected HTML code. Use the following rules.
info: No naming restrictions: use any tag name to create html elements.
Child >: This operator specifies a childe element
Multiplication *: This operator defines how many times an adjacent element should be outputted

instructions: Combine the next rules to create the result HTML tree
info: Grouping (): groups elements together, as mathematical parenthesis

subject: Attributes
instructions: As you saw in the last exercise, some attributes are auto-generated.
We can also use Attribute operators to define other attributes and their values as needed.
Most common attributes are the id and css class attributes.
info: #idNAme: The [#] notation allows specifying an id
.classNAme: The [.] notation allows specifying a class

subject: Custom Attributes
instructions: [attrName=attrValue]: This notation allows creating custom attributes
info: In addition, we can also create our own custom attributes using the bracket notation.

subject: Multiplication and Numbering
instructions: Use the $ operator to number the amount of li elements.
info: Item numbering $: The $ operator can number elements!

subject: Multiplication and Numbering
instructions: Use the $ operator to place zeroes before a number
info: several $: add zeros before a number

subject: Inner Text
instructions: How about adding inner text inside elements?
info: {text}: curly brackets allow adding inner text to our elements.
